event.title: traces its history to the days

data.event: It traces its history to the days of Raja Jaipal who ruled over, among others, the territories of Bhatinda, Samana.

event.title: was entrusted to Qutb-ud-Din Aibek in 1192

data.event: It fell into the hands of Shahab-ud-Din Muhammad Gauri after the conquest of Ajmer and Delhi and was entrusted to Qutb-ud-Din Aibek in 1192, along with the territories of Ghuram and Sunam.

event.title: is said to be a place of saints and scholars during the Mughal days

data.event: While Samana is said to be a place of saints and scholars during the Mughal days, it is notorious also for its professional executioners, who served at Delhi and Sirhind.

event.title: executed Guru Teg Bahadur at Delhi in 1675

data.event: Sayyad Jala-ud-Din, who executed Guru Teg Bahadur at Delhi in 1675 was from Samana.

event.title: the end of 1710 AD.It was retaken

data.event: But the Mughals were yet too strong for the rising power of Sikhs and Samana had to be given up by them towards the end of 1710 AD.It was retaken in about 1742 AD by Baba Ala Singh, the founder of the Patiala ruling family and was recognized as a part of his territories by Ahamd Shah Durani.

event.title: 1742 AD by Baba Ala Singh, the founder of the Patiala ruling family and was recognized

data.event: But the Mughals were yet too strong for the rising power of Sikhs and Samana had to be given up by them towards the end of 1710 AD.It was retaken in about 1742 AD by Baba Ala Singh, the founder of the Patiala ruling family and was recognized as a part of his territories by Ahamd Shah Durani.
